content:
=== Game Rules ===
This is vgdl rule file:
BasicGame square_size=32
    SpriteSet
        background > Immovable img=oryx/space1 hidden=True
        base    > Immovable    color=WHITE img=oryx/planet
        avatar  > FlakAvatar   stype=sam img=oryx/spaceship1
        missile > Missile
            sam  > orientation=UP    color=BLUE singleton=True img=oryx/bullet1
            bomb > orientation=DOWN  color=RED  speed=0.5 img=oryx/bullet2
        alien   > Bomber       stype=bomb   prob=0.01  cooldown=3 speed=0.8
            alienGreen > img=oryx/alien3
            alienBlue > img=oryx/alien1
        portal  > invisible=True hidden=True
        	portalSlow  > SpawnPoint   stype=alienBlue  cooldown=16   total=20 img=portal
        	portalFast  > SpawnPoint   stype=alienGreen  cooldown=12   total=20 img=portal

    LevelMapping
        . > background
        0 > background base
        1 > background portalSlow
        2 > background portalFast
        A > background avatar

    TerminationSet
        SpriteCounter      stype=avatar               limit=0 win=False
        MultiSpriteCounter stype1=portal stype2=alien limit=0 win=True

    InteractionSet
        avatar  EOS  > stepBack
        alien   EOS  > turnAround
        missile EOS  > killSprite

        base bomb > killBoth
        base sam > killBoth scoreChange=1

        base   alien > killSprite
        avatar alien > killSprite scoreChange=-1
        avatar bomb  > killSprite scoreChange=-1
        alien  sam   > killSprite scoreChange=2

This is vgdl rule in natural language:
This game is essentially a classic space shooter with a twist. You control a spaceship (the “avatar”) flying in a space‐scene background. Enemies (“aliens”) are spawned by hidden portal objects that periodically release alien types (one that moves a bit slower, one faster). The aliens drop bombs as they fly (their “bomb” projectiles), while your ship fires “sam” projectiles upward (blue, singleton bullet) to take them out.

Here are the key points:

• Genre and Mechanics
 – It’s a space shooter/arcade game where your ship can move around and fire projectiles.
 – The player’s ship (“avatar”) must dodge enemy aliens and their bombs.
 – There are obstacles such as a “base” (a planet image) and possibly shield-like structures (the level layout shows blocks labeled with 0’s) which might have an extra role in the gameplay.
 – Enemies reverse direction when they hit the edge of the screen, and your ship is kept within bounds (if it hits a screen edge it “steps back”).
 – Projectiles are used by both sides: you shoot “sam” projectiles upward; aliens drop “bombs” downward at a slow speed, and there are also “missiles” that are quickly removed when reaching screen boundaries.

• Objective and Win/Loss Conditions
 – Your main goal is to eliminate the alien threat.
 – The win condition isn’t just about clearing aliens on screen; it is defined by a MultiSpriteCounter checking that both the portals (enemy spawners) and aliens vanish. This means you must ideally neutralize the enemy spawn points and finish off any aliens they’ve released.
 – You lose if your ship (“avatar”) is destroyed (when its counter drops to zero).

• How Interactions Work
 – When your ship’s projectile (“sam”) hits an alien, the alien is destroyed and you score points (+2).
 – Colliding with an alien (or with an enemy bomb) directly with your ship causes a penalty (-1) and removes the enemy sprite.
 – There’s also an interesting interaction where if “sam” hits the “base,” both get destroyed and you gain a small score boost (+1). At the same time, if a bomb hits the base, both are killed. This suggests the base might be a double‐edged sword: it could be a protective or scoring object, but it’s also vulnerable to enemy attacks.
 – Missiles that reach the edge of the screen are simply removed, keeping the action contained.

• Overall Strategy
 – Stay mobile and keep your ship away from enemy aliens and falling bombs. The penalty for direct collision means dodging is crucial.
 – Focus on shooting aliens with your “sam” projectiles. Successfully hitting them not only gives you points (with a high reward per hit) but also prevents them from reaching and possibly destroying the base.
 – Manage the pace of enemy spawns by targeting the portals indirectly (since the win condition requires eliminating both aliens and their spawn points). You’ll need to clear aliens quickly as more are spawned over time.
 – Use the boundaries to your advantage. Since the ship is forced back if it gets too high or too close to the screen edge, position yourself centrally where you can react to bombs and alien maneuvers.
 – Protect valuable assets (like the base) if they serve a role in your defense or scoring, but be cautious—allowing bombs to hit the base can remove it and might complicate the battle.

In short, the game asks you to balance offense (shooting aliens to earn points and clear the field) with careful defense (dodging alien collisions and bombs, and possibly managing the base’s integrity). Smart movement and precision shooting are essential to eventually eliminate both the alien forces and their spawning portals to secure victory.

You are an intelligent player playing a video game, and you have a friend provide you strategy. Interpret the state, rule, strategy and act accordingly. Notice that your avatar position is one of the most important information, if the position doesn't change from the last state, you need to analyze the state and make a different action from the last time.

=== Available Actions ===
0: ACTION_NIL
1: ACTION_USE
2: ACTION_LEFT
3: ACTION_RIGHT

=== Important Mechanics Notice ===
 In some games, directional actions (LEFT, RIGHT, UP, DOWN) may first cause the avatar to rotate toward the intended direction without immediately moving. If the avatar's position does not change after a directional action, it may indicate a rotation has occurred. To proceed, you must apply the directional action again after rotation. Always verify whether the avatar actually moved after each action. Please understand the rule and the interaction set first, then locate the item, finally choose a meaningful action towards the win and respond in the format: ``` Action:<action number> ```. Include one sentence of feedback on the action and your expectation to see if it aligns with the strategy. Notice, Action 0 will not reasult in any change in this game environment, and you may need to understand the level layout first to play the game.

Action:3

I'm moving right to reposition under the base at column 22, so that my next sam shot (once properly aligned) can target and remove the base formation, potentially opening a path as planned.

=== Sprite Mapping ===

background -> '.'
background base -> '0'
background portalSlow -> '1'
background portalFast -> '2'
alienBlue -> '@'
base -> '#'
sam -> '$'
alienBlue bomb -> '%'
bomb -> '&'

===Long-term Plan===
```**avatar strategy: Utilize sam to trigger base interactions, dissolving base clusters that form the wall blockage in the congested corridor; systematically batch-process nearby base objects with sam until a free path emerges, and if the blockade persists, reassign target priorities with **Alert****```

Action:3

I'm moving right from (10,17) toward aligning under the base cluster at column 22 so that I can subsequently fire sam to neutralize the base and clear the corridor, which is in line with our long-term strategy.
